reviewContent: Super arrogant and not helpful security staff. Cannot imagine going through security check not being able to understand english. The staff I encountered was the worst person ever!

Terrible experience at this airport! The labeling of the airport transit system is totally confusing. The train stations are labeled 1,3,4,5. What happened to No. 2? Then there is another station after 5 but not labeled with a name! That’s the station we needed to get to but it looked like it was Station 5! Also the parking lots should have different naming system from the terminals. We parked in G lot. But G is also one of the terminals! When riding the train, we thought we should get off at station 4 where G terminal is but actually we needed to get off at the last station, the one with no name! The design of the naming system is a mess!

commentHeader: give credit where it was due
reviewContent: We found one particular member of ground staff at the automatic check in extremely helpful & friendly as we were having difficulty using it.. Also for my first time I needed wheelchair assistance ( twisted knee). These staff also were helpful thro security and to the gate. Most customers are quick to complain but slow to compliment so I wanted to give credit where it was due!

As a lifelong Chicagoan, I was embarrassed at the lack of cleanliness outside the terminals at O'Hare. Please power wash the sidewalks and paint structures. Gum is stuck all over the sidewalk and its filthy. Mayor Daley would never have put up with this!  I wish I had taken photos.

I’m an international student and I had to stop at Chicago airport to get a flight to LAX and my mom was with me. We needed to recheck in our bags and I mistakenly went to the wrong room. Since I was the only one who spoke the language I went to an old lady to ask her where I could recheck in my bags and then she questioned me and started to scream at me and my mom who doesn’t know the language. Then we went back in and checked our bags again. After I left I went to apologize to her and she told me to “go and learn”! Like I get it that I made a mistake but that does not justify her behavior towards me and my mom

We had a terrible experience transiting at this so called airport. At security checking we ended up queing twice in the wrong queue because they only informed us as you get nearby the entrance! The time wasted meant we go without washroom breaks and any shopping, else we miss our flight. We arrived at gate B14 and departed at C11, a very long walk. Also need to point out, for some reason the man doing the security checks in our cue was extremely slow at his job, we could hear other passengers also saying “why is this man so slow at his job”. Why was there no supervisor present to notice these inconsistencies. We will be avoiding US airports in future travels.

Avoid this airport, disaster at every opportunity. I understand it’s a very big and busy place but management has their heads so far up their keysters they can’t see the light of day. Make a strategic effort management take a step back and replan, redo and re-execute the entire operation from beginning to end. Give the customer what they need and deserve.
Unable to find an outlet that was functioning to charge my phone, staff not willing to assist, very dirty, multiple gate changes and poorly updated on gate changes.

My husband and I were traveling home from European vacation. Our flight itinerary included a connection to final flight home (Orlando) through O'Hare. The entire experience was a complete cluster with no clear direction or informative staff. The process for visitors to exit the customs area from international arrivals was embarrassingly long and lacking in clear directions. I was chatting up a baggage handler to get some logistical direction for how to proceed from the customs verification area. The long, long line of people trying to get out of terminal 5 and make their way toward connecting flight terminals or even to exit airport was appalling. There should have been multilingual employees serving as ambassadors to assist passengers who did not speak English well or at all. We had to pick up our luggage and literally re-check it AND go through security protocol all over again as if we had just walked in off the street to begin our journey. We had to interrupt airport staff from personal conversations to ask for direction! We had to ask several times from more than one person who we assumed worked for the airport, which way to get to our terminal (had to move from terminal 5 to 1 to catch connecting flight), which way to TSA pre-check for security, and which line to get in when there appeared to be redundant, contradicting signs. There needs to be some intensive review of the entire customer experience for this airport. It was unfriendly, confusing, and left much to be desired for welcoming international guests. Logisics is #1 need followed by customer service training as #2.

Better than Midway, but that’s an extremely low bar. Confusing and absent signage. Not enough elevators for people with disabilities or strollers. Some staff extremely helpful while others couldn’t care less. This place can be hectic and crowded on any given day, but overall it seems disorganized between check in and baggage. I would say the biggest issue is spread out layout, and need to travel really far to get to one place and then another. Missed more than one flight because elevators were full and people standing around in line blocking walking paths. Needs to be streamlined and simpler. Who designed this corn maze of an airport anyway?

commentHeader: shocked by the level of degradation"
reviewContent: I didn't use ORD for several years and was completely shocked by the level of degradation. Now it's third world class. I Will try to avoid flying from Chicago in the future.

The staff refused to help me find the airport train. She said she didn’t have time for that. Actually make me cry. Reminded me of when I was picking up my mother there years ago, and was yelled at by an employee for pulling up and waiting for her. Who do they think pays their salaries? Get a different job if you can’t be kind!

commentHeader: staff just kept screaming at people
reviewContent: On our first trip to America we had our layover at Chicago O’Hare both coming and going. When we arrived we were surprised that the queues weren’t as long as we had feared and the man who checked our passports were nice enough. Going through security a woman kept screaming “Step up! Step up!” so we avoided her at all costs. The personnel just kept sighing and seemed really annoyed to have to deal with passengers. On our return flight they were even worse. I wasn’t allowed to accompany my daughter as I had the previous time. She has social anxiety so that wasn’t very pleasant for her. The staff just kept screaming at people what to do and were super rude. I get that this is their job and they do this every day, but most people don’t fly every day and being nicer shouldn’t be that hard. When we had gone through security and arrived at the international terminal we went to buy some water and sandwiches at a self checkout and some guy asked us if we needed a bag. When I said no he said in a super angry tone that he still had to see that my payment went through. I guess we looked like criminals? I went to the bathroom and got looked in. Finally managed to get out. Same thing happened to my daughter later in the day. We had an 11 hour layover and all the seats were really uncomfortable. I hurt all over when we finally got in our plane. (That the guy in front of me had his seat fully reclined the whole 8+ hour flight is another story) We were in Arizona for 10 days and didn’t meet a single rude person in all that time and the personnel at Phoenix Harbor were very pleasant. Extreme difference between the two airports. Doesn’t make me want to ever visit Chicago.

I thought Pearson airport was bad, but Chicago may be worse! Never met so many rude staff, except for that one gentleman who works for United who assisted us rather than forcing their rules on us. The other staff couldn't care less, the attitude of another was just another level when we had simply asked for directions. Apart from their unprofessionalism, the walk from arrivals is so long. The design of this Airport just sucks. I have no other words, except that this experience definitely deters me from ever visiting Chicago.

I just want to get off my plane. We landed over 40 minutes ago and we are stuck in a holding area. They have sent us to 3 gates already and each one has a plane already in it. This is the most unorganized, ridiculous airport I’ve ever flown in or out of!

commentHeader: just want to get out of this airport
reviewContent: So cold, everyone is complaining. Food is terrible but most airports have terrible food now. Seats are very cold and uncomfortable. The air smells bad, I just want to get out of this airport.

commentHeader: a perfect example of a failed Airport
reviewContent: This is truly a perfect example of a failed Airport. Nothing works, staff are rude the wait line for immigration is at times over 2 hours which is totally unacceptable. Voters should immediately take this airport away from Politicians running it to a private enterprise. Shame on you Chicago.

The rudest people on the planet work here. TSA thinks they can treat you poorly simply because of their plastic badge. There are literally signs every 5 feet in the security line telling you that you have to remove anything larger than a cell phone from your bag. When I was attempting to remove my tablet, the TSA employee just kept saying over & over & over...(looking right at me) "everything stays in your bag". I politely asked why the sign indicated otherwise, and he just stared at me and said "everything stays in your bag". He wouldn't admit the sign states differently. After I finally passed through the metal detector, I got yelled at from another person, who takes her plastic badge very seriously, because I didn't put my bin away. TSA security was nothing but 20 minutes of being yelled at, being told we weren't making straight enough lines, moving too fast, moving too slow & getting ridiculed. They all roll their eyes & look at each other & snicker when someone doesn't do exactly what they think they should be doing. They really need to fix their system instead of getting mad when we can't understand why there are outdated signs. When we got to our gate, the woman working had zero patience for simple questions. We will use Milwaukee next time. Or any other airport not associated with Chicago where everyone hates their job! Just the worst airport. Perhaps they need to understand that a majority of the population doesn't fly on a regular basis. A little compassion & patience can go a long way. It must be exhausting being a TSA employee at O'Hare and being a miserable person every second of every day. I didn't want to give a 1 rating. I wanted to give a zero, but that wasn't an option. Do better, people. O'Hare is an embarrassment to the human race.

commentHeader: rudest people I have ever encountered
reviewContent: The TSA were the absolute rudest people I have ever encountered in an airport. They confiscated several items and didn’t even give us an opportunity to check them in.

commentHeader: airport has never been world class
reviewContent: Better than under Lori Lightfoot when thousands of homeless made this home. However lacks all world class airport charm. This airport has never been world class and never will be. IL politicians are to blame I see third world nations build faster airports than Chicago.

commentHeader: staff are seriously rude and unprofessional
reviewContent: Avoid this airport like the plague if you have a short layover and you want to make it in time for your flight. The lines move slower than a snail and some of the staff are seriously rude and unprofessional. For an airport of this size, it is so poorly organized that newcomers will have to go on a scavenger hunt to find their gate, if it's not already very close by. If your gate is in a different terminal, good luck actually finding it without stopping to ask for directions. I had about twenty minutes to get to my gate before the doors would close, but my flight wasn't listed on any of the departure screens in Terminal 1, so I had to hear it from a staff member that my gate number would be on a departure screen in Terminal 3. Which meant ten minutes wasted traveling by train all the way to Terminal 3, only to find out that the gate itself is actually located in Terminal 2. The icing on the cake was that my gate was E5, but there were literally no signs at all in Terminal 3 that gave any sort of hint as to where the E gates were. Which makes absolutely no sense, since that was where they sent me to find my gate. I had to hear it from a staff member that I was in the wrong terminal, but not before asking at least four different people and getting no answer at all. The security lady decided to give me attitude when all I asked was how to find the E gates from Terminal 3. She told me that I needed to get through security first, which again, makes absolutely no sense at all and is basically no answer. So to sum it all up, this is one of the worst airports ever if you are in a hurry or you have a connecting flight. You will find here slow moving lines, unhelpful and rude staff, and no way to get to the correct gate without having to go on a scavenger hunt, which most people don't have time to do.

Air conditioning wasn't working in the e-gate section. It was very hot in that wing and humid. Additionally the PA system wasn't working so it was hard to hear information about our flight. No airport officials were present to offer water or assist with anything. The terminal was also dirty and dingy. The only good thing I can say is that TSA here was efficient.

commentHeader: hard to find a worse airport
reviewContent: It would be hard to find a worse airport than Chicago O'Hare airport. The traffic, the parking, the poor signage, the rude employees that obviously dislike their jobs, the flight congestion, on and on. Try to avoid if at all possible! This airport is an embarrassment and everyone knows it. Hard to believe there is no accountability for any of it.

We arrived from Munich airport, where it was very clean, organized and smooth process to get to our gate and board the plane. Arriving to Chicago O'Hare was a shock. Very dirty, rude staff who were yelling at everyone. It is not my imagination to say there were at least 5000 passenger entering this big area (under construction!) and there were only 5 officers checking passports. We all pretty much missed our connecting flights and had to scramble to get a Hotel for the night and the process repeated itself again the next morning. So disappointed to see one of the biggest cities in US and one of the biggest airport in the world was an absolute disaster. I make sure I will not ever travel through O'Hare and also make sure to discourage everyone I know not to consider this airport as an option.

The security is terrible. I was frisked down because I gave the security a bit of attitude after they rolled their eyes at me and aggressively yelled at me to unload my things. Any time I asked a question it was like I was in the wrong. The TSA does not care about anyone who comes through. If you can find a different airport, do so.

I have never experienced such rude and mean security staff. They laughed at me when I didn't push my carry on luggage through, and took my souvenirs and carelessly scattered them. The whole process is extremely difficult, slow and confusing.

Do everything you can to avoid this airport. There are good workers here but it’s not enough to overcome the atrocious design and apparent lack of investment by airlines and the city. You will be delayed. You will have a terrible time in customs. You will have a terrible time getting through security. They will change your gate at least 3 times (to different terminals). You will be shocked at the lack of food and drink options (as bad as the old Kansas City airport if you can believe it). You will get lost due to bad/conflicting signage. They will try to charge you $10 for a sticker (souvenir for the kid). No one will care about any of that or be there to answer your questions. This place should be condemned. I saw an article indicating they invested $8.5 billion here. Someone should be invested for fraud, there is no indication of upgrades. Good luck if you are forced to use this god forsaken place.

Connecting through Terminal 5 on the way back to Heathrow. Hardly any restaurants with seats or retail outlets to help pass time. Staff at the Wow Boa and Urban Olive were uniformly rude, bordering on aggressive. The food was basic rubbish at restaurant prices. I get airports are more expensive but at least try! I give UK infrastructure a hard time but none of its airports are as bad as this place. Will never travel through here again.
Had connecting flight out of terminal K. Absolutely filthy. Food court tables were sticky and hadn’t been swept under. Counter in that area of covered in dust. All trash cans were overflowing.

commentHeader: TSA well organized, check in very friendly
reviewContent: TSA well organized, check in very friendly, After TSA airport employee personnel standing around in large groups, blocking passage. Language used was unacceptable, felt like being on a street corner. Seems like employees should have a break area rather than grouping in gate areas eating lunch or on breaks and acting like at a home party with the enormously loud laughter and joking. I also think the cell phones should be put away when working as it does not make anyplace look like the employees are needed when they walk around on the cell. O'Hare has a lot of employees who seem focused and dedicated, also very friendly, but it also seems like a lot of the hiring was done by a friend as a lot of them seem to be hanging out.

I was traveling back to the country from a short vacation in Cancun Mexico with my spouse. So coming in we had to land from Cancun, navigate immigration/customs - get to trams and to departing gates to reach my domestic flight to get home. It was simply the most backward, unorganized mess of a process I have ever had in any airport. After lines to do that we got through and had to go through the baggage area even though we only had carry on bags. So we had to get into an free for all mess with hundreds of foreigners cramming to shrink into one line to get pas a chokehold were a customs officer selected those to get searched. After this we then lucked out and after being given bad information from a security or police officer that was working an information booth my wife and I lucked out and got on a tram and found the right way to now to to our gate of departure. Now another security screening, everyone goes through the same. line, We finally got through and ran to our gate and directly on to the gate and made it out on time. With not a minute to spare. We have to do better.  Honestly, its intolerable. I will never fly through Chicago again.

commentHeader: 86 minutes for our bags to arrive
reviewContent: I took a layover flight, so I could spend a few hours with my daughter that I haven't seen in over a year. It took 86 minutes for our bags to arrive at the carousel. I expected 30 minutes max. This takes my 2.5 hours with her down to 1.5 hours. So unacceptable

commentHeader: The layout is one long corridor
reviewContent: Horrible airport. The layout is one long corridor and you may need to walk almost the whole distance twice if you checked a bag for arrival. There aren’t enough baggage stations for the number of flights, to the point where two or more international flights will have to share a station. I didn’t get my baggage until more than an hour after my flight arrived. The airport is also clearly understaffed. If I had to say one good thing about the airport, I can say the bathrooms by the flight gates are clean, although I can’t say the same of those by baggage claim.

commentHeader: worst airport I have ever been too
reviewContent: Likely the worst airport I have ever been too. The staff are truly useless. The slowest moving and dumbest people you will meet on your journey. The seating is awful. The outlet placement is awful. It’s a terrible design. If you can avoid this airport please do. Ohare and Laurie Lightfoot take pride in being the best airport in the United States. I have looked into that ranking system. They are not the best, obviously anybody who has been here can verify that. Ohare is the busiest. Way too many people. Constantly understaffed. Truly a terrible experience every single time.

This airport is filthy! The bathrooms were dirty and in ill repair. There was nowhere to hang purse or coats. Toilets were not clean and there was a strong smell of urine. A little bleach would go a long way. There weren't many places to plug in devices to recharge. TSA was dirty and there were way too many people in one place. One area of the floor was filled with water which we had to walk through. For an International airport, it's a disgrace.

One of the most horrible airport experience my family had. Concerning luggage, We checked in all our baggage for transfer to Philadelphia and they were all in good shape. However, when we claimed them in Philadelphia we were shocked that couple of the bags were opened that the entire zipper was ruined that it was put together by a tape by whoever that person to keep parts of it closed but still you can see the contents inside. When we opened it at home some of the stuff were missing, and the contents were in a shamble. And one of our bags is missing.

I frequently fly out of Chicago, and the first time I experienced customs here, I thought maybe it was a fluke. Maybe they are understaffed or don’t know better. Nope. As a US citizen returning to my own country, customs should not take 3 hours. It has happened to me three times in the last two years. Why can they not figure out to put returning citizens and other visas into separate lines? This is an absolute joke. Arriving in other countries is easier than going home. I don’t know if other airports have this problem, if all of the US is this bad, or if it’s just Chicago. I hate this airport, and would stop using it if it wasn’t my best option without traveling 5 hours.

commentHeader: dirtiest airport I have ever experienced
reviewContent: I was here on a 2 hour layover. By far the dirtiest airport I have ever experienced. Bathrooms were disgusting to say the least. And finding feminine hygiene products was almost impossible. I visited 3 stores that sold them but had none in stock, before luckily finding a vending machine. The Reuben I got at the Blackhawks bar and grill was delicious and the bartender was great. I also picked up some Chicago mix popcorn at a Nuts on Clark kiosk. Maneuvering the airport was pretty easy, no problems there. Just would have liked to have had a cleaner experience. The entire airport seemed unsanitary to me from the bathrooms, to the restaurants, down to the seating areas.

I arrived in Chicago O'Hare at 6:18 pm and had to make a connecting flight which required me to recheck my bag. My connecting flight wasn't until 9:10 PM. I designed this so that I would have plenty of time to go through customs, recheck my bag, and eat dinner before my next flight. That might be true at most airports but not at O'Hare! The customs line was inefficient and took way too long. I think O'Hare needs to look at how other airports (such as Atlanta) manage customs lines. They have a lot to learn. Once through the line, everyone was callous, rude, and unhelpful. I was moved back a significant number of spaces (Maybe 10?) in the baggage recheck line, simply because one of the workers changed the queue line while I was in it so that others could go ahead. Then I had to go back through airport security, which is apparently always a disaster in the evenings at O'Hare. Not a separate security line, but the same security line someone who has just checked into their flight for the first time has to go through. The line wasn't moving, the workers were extremely rude, and I had olive oil I purchased in Croatia confiscated because it was "suspicious" even though it was in the proper marked bag for customs. Not to mention, the worker took an extraordinarily long time to check the marked bags, and cut them open. I missed my flight (even though I had a 3 hour cushion), never got dinner because all restaurants closed, and had to sleep in the airport overnight or risk having the rest of my items confiscated since she cut the customs bag open. Absolutely horrible experience from start to finish. I will make extra efforts to fly through Atlanta from now on. They seem to know what they are doing there.

ORD is an abysmal airport with respect to customer service, signage, and efficiency. Our flight from Paris arrived late to ORD and we were in a panic to get to our connection to Atl. The long walk to customs was ridiculous! We asked a person about MPC and she pointed us to the ridiculous line which took almost an hour to get through, with only one person “helping” travelers. When we finally got to the customs agent he said we could have gone to a shorter line. So basically we were given bad info from the one worker facilitating the line. Then, we had to collect our bags, but none of the carousel signage had our flight on it. Again no one was around for help, but when I finally saw someone she was very rude and no help at all. After we finally found our luggage, we had to try and find info on how to get to Delta. No signs! Someone at AA told us we had to go back out to take the train to the designated terminal. And then check bags and go through security again. What a complete joke of an airport that is a prime example of a nightmare. Needless to say we missed our connection. We did get another flight so we went to the tiny Sky Lounge in 2E. The bathrooms were dirty, the ladies room had a broken soap container, and TP all over the floor. Avoid connecting through this airport at all costs. Or allow at least 4 hours if coming from an international flight. It’s too bad the airlines don’t plan for longer connection times.

Without even a close contender, this was the worst airport experience of my life. I arrived from Spain and had a connecting to LAX with just over two hours between. The instructions for navigation between customs, immigration/baggage, recheck baggage, security, transition between terminals and gate location were nearly non-existent and posted directions offered no meaningful help. Asking for help was equally non-productive as most airport staff seemed uncaring, unhelpful, distracted and most aggravating, poorly trained. I approached one "information desk" to inquire as to how to get from the arrival terminal to Terminal 3 - with my bags. The instructions were basically "go outside, turn left and go upstairs." I had left Santiago de Compostelo, Spain nearly 18 hours previous, I am 70 years old and have Addisons's disease. I replied, that I just didn't believe that physically I was able to make it. The young man simply turned away, not to help someone else, simply turned his back. I was finally able to get assistance by tagging along with someone in a wheel chair who had an airport attendant. My flight boarded late apparently due to airport congestion preventing the plane from approaching the gate. Repeatedly having the boarding/departure times changed resulted in virtually all passengers standing for more than 45 minutes. There are no "queue" lines and passengers just grouped - congesting the walk ways. I might have been able to put up with all of the incompetence were it not for the "canned" voice of the mayor of Chicago (I assume it's an election year) coming on the PA system more often than the meaningful and necessary announcements to brag on O'Hare as an excellent, award winning airport. It was like shining a spotlight on the poor design, untrained staff, non-existent directional signs, and just plain lack of caring for tired travelers.

International departures - terminal 5 is very poor. Going through security I was asked to unzip my top - for an under wired bra search. Unbelievable. Once through security, there is barely any seating. The majority of shops are closed. Restaurant/food choices are minimal and ridiculously expensive and airport staff were generally rude. Signage around the airport is also poor. I ordered a Burger King meal and Pepsi without ice. When the drink arrived, it came with ice which I don’t like. I requested one without ice per my order and was told I couldn’t change my order. I explained I wasn’t changing my order, I simply wanted to have what I had ordered in the first place. I was then told I had to have ice in my drink as it was allegedly ‘airport policy’. Customer service couldn’t have been more disinterested and I’d love to know why an airport is dictating whether or not I have ice in my drink. Utterly ridiculous.

commentHeader: not the airport it once was
reviewContent: Chicago O'Hare in 2022 is not the airport it once was. I wouldn't know the airport it once was, because I'm 33 and it's been on a downhill trend for my entire life. Yes they're trying to make improvements and I've even heard rumors of a major terminal construction project, but the airport doesn't feel like it belongs in the first world. TSA staff are rude, the terminal (5) is crowded, the seating is falling apart. As I write this I moved seats three times to find one that wasn't dirty or broken (Gate M20, TAP Airlines). They recently re did the train between terminals but it took a ridiculous number of years to complete, and terminal transfer was hell for that entire time. Chicago deserves a much better airport than O'hare. I would recommend flying through Milwaukee if at all possible, or if your traveling internationally, arrive in NY, Houston, ATL etc and connect to your final destination.

Arrived from LAX for a transfer to LHR from Terminal 5. This was my first time at ORD, and hopefully will be my last. Thankfully I had a reasonable transfer time as the airport experience was a total hideous ordeal and frankly an embarrassment to the operators. Signage is useless, the transit train was rammed - with the door inexplicably opening and closing without reason, but the worst part was the ridiculous security queue. There seems to be no priority queue for those holding a premium cabin ticket, but the guy who was ‘directing’ the queue should be removed with immediate effect. There is signage in the cattle pens that indicates the requirement to be polite and courteous to TSA staff, but that deal should work both ways. The big guy who was on duty in T5 on Sep 9th was shouting at passengers like animals. He was rude and quite frankly a bully. I suspect he may have been bullied as a kid and was venting his frustration at tired and annoyed passengers. An awful experience and hopefully I will never have to experience that hell hole again.

Worst airport experience ever. I had a 3 hour connection at this airport, but I spent more than 3 hours waiting in line just to get through customs! There were no fast lines for connections, but just one line. The people near customs were shouting at us to get in line, but were no helpful at all and the wifi was barely working. I missed my flight, the airline said it was not their fault and they could not do anything to help me except for rebooking me on the next flight, that was 17 hours later. I had to sleep on a bench at the airport waiting for my flight. The temperature was really freezing, I had to put on 2 jackets. Really bad experience.

commentHeader: we spent 3 hours waiting in line
reviewContent: Worst airport ever. We had a 2 and a half hour connection at this airport, but we spent 3 hours waiting in line just to get through customs! First of all, why do we even need to go through customs if I am literally leaving the country 2 hours later and won't even get out of the airport. We missed our flight, the airline said it was not their fault and they could not do anything to help us and the next flight was 24 hours later. We had to rent a terrible motel near the airport and wait for our flight. There were no fast lines for connections. The people near customs were shouting at us to get in line, but were no helpful at all and the wifi was barely working. Really bad experience.

commentHeader: what a joke of an airport
reviewContent: Flew in to terminal 5 more or less on time and the plane was made to taxi around the entire length of the runaway to get to the gate. The pilot wasn’t impressed over the intercom. That was the first delay. Finally got to the terminal to be met by massive queues. I had 1 and half hours to get through to my connecting flight so I thought I might be ok -  from point of landing to crossing the border it took 2 hours! I kept asking staff if I could skip ahead, no one had any interest in helping what so ever and wouldn’t help. Half the border control posts were unmanned so that didn’t help. I of course missed my next flight. Got to the American help desk and no flights available and no help what so ever. Only way to get to my next destination was to get a hire car and drive. All I can say is what a joke of an airport. If you can’t handle the volume of traffic coming through then they shouldn’t be allowed to sell tickets with transfers. Either that or sort out the infrastructure and staff. Let ticketed transfers in to another queue or utilise what you have and actually man the desks! Looking at other reviews this isn’t a one off. I won’t use this airport again. As an international traveller having been on the plane for over 8 hours was also very disappointed by lack of food and drink and no working wifi

commentHeader: conditions of terminal five are very poor
reviewContent: The line to get through customs at Terminal 5 was about a half a mile long. There was one long line with very few customers employees on duty. There were plumbing issues with the ladies restrooms while waiting in the customs area for 2+ hours. The conditions of terminal five are very poor and appear to be understaffed.

commentHeader: need more officers to speed up this process
reviewContent: August 9th my 9yr old, my husband & I arrived at Chicago O'Hare after a 4hr flight, a 3 hr layover & a 14hr nonstop flight from Dubai to Chicago & soon after we exited the plane we saw signs for US citizens & visitors to follow right side of the rope & Universal passport holders on the left side. This led us down a 2 hour excruciatingly tiresome long line that probably spanned the entire length of the airport to the Customs & Immigration counter. There were tired little kids fussing, including my daughter who got sick on the airplane. There was couple who had a connecting flight & they politely asked one of employees monitoring the flow of passengers if they can skip ahead as their connecting flight was boarding in 20 minutes, they were allowed to skip further up but I don't know if they made their connecting flight & they were still 5 people ahead of them. The Immigration officers take their reviewing documents while masses of hungry & tired passengers are waiting in long lines. After we finally made it through customs, we couldn't figure out where the baggage claim for our airline was since the TV screens were showing only most recently arrived flights & not the ones that arrived 2 hrs ago. The employees were not helpful, so we looked around for other passengers from our flight & followed them. We found 2 of 3 luggages rather quickly but there no carts to be found. Many passengers including us ran around looking for carts & after 20 minutes we finally found one, we still needed to follow another line to handover the Immigration declaration card at the exit, thankfully this took only 20 minutes. They need to do a better job of making more groups or categories at the Immigration lines to speed up the process for people who have connecting flights, people traveling with young children etc. They need more officers to speed up this process. It's atrocious! Even when we left for Dubai couple of weeks ago the security check in took almost 2 hours. So yes you do need to be at the airport at least 3 hours ahead of your flight & God Bless you if you have a connecting flight at O'Hare.

Arrived at Terminal 5; mixed reviews. I was pleasantly surprised at the cleanliness of the bathroom and ease of getting through to baggage claim but then it went downhill fast. It was quite a long wait for the bags to come out and then everyone from all the belts had to get through customs check but there was no organization to that at all- just many lanes of people having to condense into one lane where there was only one agent collecting global entry or customs forms. He wasn’t checking anything. Once through that mess, it was not clear how to get to the trains- very poor signage. For a major international airport it was a disappointing experience that could easily be fixed with a little more organization and a few signs. Thankfully all staff we interacted with were friendly and helpful. I would suggest if you are coming in on an international flight and have to make a connection, plan a 3-hour layover or you will likely miss your connecting flight.

I fly internationally for a living. Terminal 5 at Chicago o'hare is absolutely the worst experience in my entire career. An International wing with only one Burger King restaurant and other options open during the mid morning. This would be fine if you were traveling out a new to pack a lunch before you came to the airport. No charging stations at the gates. Horrible experience from beginning to end.

Security employees were great at the international terminal but otherwise the terminal is a disaster. Half of the stores/restaurants closed, seating is terrible and in bad shape, overall disappointing.

commentHeader: cannot believe how difficult it was to locate the ride share area
reviewContent: I cannot believe how difficult it was to locate the ride share area. I fly all the time and have had an easier time locating the ride share area in other countries/languages. Additionally, when I attempted to go up the wrong elevator in my confusion, the man that addressed me was incredibly rude. This obviously only heightened my frustration with this airport. To be honest, if that man had just kindly helped me, I probably wouldn’t have cared how hard it was to locate my pick up area.

This is one crowded airport. The United concourses are brightly lit with clear signage. Connecting to an international flight requires taking the inter terminal train to Terminal 5. Despite it being a very warm day (90 degree temperatures), the AC was not effective. Train carriages were rather warm. Terminal 5 needs a major renovation. Upon disembarking from the train, there was one long narrow line to go through TSA once again. Passengers who arrive on connecting domestic flights shouldn't have to go through TSA twice. The concourses are very crowded and the lighting could be better. There are signs posted re terminal renovation/expansion which is desperately needed.

commentHeader: It was definitely survival of the fittest
reviewContent: We just returned from a long delayed trip to Scandinavia and Great Britain. I wonderful trip - including attending a family wedding. Unfortunately, we returned via O’Hare with a connecting flight to our hometown in Wisconsin. Our SAS flight from Copenhagen was great - we arrived on time. Once we were arrived at the International terminal - a whole different story. Long lines for passport check - which was fine - we had a 3 hour layover for our flight home. You were geared through the line - yelled at by what seemed like over worked employees to move here, move there, etc. Got through with a passport stamp and a stamp on our customs declaration card and thought ok - not too bad. Next - loud announcements ordering us to get our checked luggage (which had been checked through to our final destination) before going through customs. We found the baggage carousel with people packed around - and had an anxious two hour wait for our bags to arrive. All the while - customs agents walked around with dogs sniffing hand luggage for illegal contraband like an orange or an apple. I like dogs - so this was okay. During that two hour wait - many of our fellow passengers were in despair that they had missed their flights. Once we got our bags - we went through another line with our bags past a single agent who took our stamped customs card. That was the customs check. We then had to find the American desk (no signs) and recheck our bags. They agent there said just leave your bags there and run / you have an hour to your flight. We ran to the train to get to our terminal. We then had to go back through security - where there was a line. When waiting in line - someone told us to go to number 7 instead. We ran in the direction he was pointing - as no idea what no. 7 meant. Got to another security line - made it through. Got to our gate just in time. Flight delayed a little so finally able to use rest room. Got on the plane - sat on the tarmac for two hours due to backed up traffic. Then storms hit - flight cancelled. The American Airlines crew was apologetic. Off the plane - in long line that did not move to get rescheduled. Gave up - no flights for at least 24 hours. No help from American couldn’t even get close to the front of the line after waiting an hour. No help therefore with food (managed to buy two donuts before they closed) - no help with hotel. Nothing available nearby online. Missed the last bus home. Spent about 2 hours finding our luggage- went to three different luggage carousels. At that point we were operating on rumors from other passengers on where luggage might be. At about 1:30 in the morning after being up for about 24 hours - we booked seats on a bus for 7 in the morning and spent the night in a noisy, freezing cold, uncomfortable airport. No food available obviously. I had some chocolate in my bag that the dogs didn’t care about in customs. That and the two donuts we managed to buy. It was definitely survival of the fittest - were old (60’s and 70’s) but in good shape. We made it home after being up for about 35 hours. We were amazed by our welcome to the US.

commentHeader: has the rudest employees we have ever met
reviewContent: We are from Michigan and have traveled all over the world, so we fly through O’Hare often. It hands down has the rudest employees we have ever met. You can always count on getting yelled at at some point. We left Charles De Gaulle airport, where the people couldn’t have been more lovely and helpful, and landed at O’Hare only to get yelled at. Our reaction was, “Well, I guess we’re home.” So much for “Midwest Nice.”

My wife and I were headed from Florence Italy to Indianapolis. Every airport we went through was efficient and kind. When we got to O'Hare we had to go through customs. I understand. Then we had to go through another inspection. I don't understand but I will do it. On this second inspection we were told to go here and to go there and to go back and to etc. Finally we got through the inspections. The people were rude and unhelpful. My wife and I could not use the restroom or get a drink of water or get anything to eat. There wasn't enough time. When we got done with the inspections we ran to the terminal to get our plane. We were late just from our arrival and the inspections we needed and their inefficiency. We were the last persons getting on the plane. There was nothing to eat or drink on the plane. Fortunately, they did have a restroom.

commentHeader: The staff were friendly and efficient
reviewContent: The transit train between terminals works well. The staff were friendly and efficient. My main issue are directions and signage. Thankfully there were plenty of people to ask. Picking up signs for T5 was tricky. We had to go through security again which was a pain and it wasn’t clear until the end of the line that we could have gone through a pre checked line. Having said that, although we had to queue, it was efficient. There is no working WiFi at T5 and we had to hunt around for charging points for our phones which actually worked. It would have been nice to get a hot drink at our food outlet.

This was my first visit to the United States and the airport experience is quite horrible I must say. I used Terminal 3 for my flight and found the airport extremely uninspiring for a long wait. There are hardly any seating areas which are comfortable or allow you to rest without being in the middle of crowds all the time. The charging points are very few and uncomfortable to use. The options for food are limited and crowded. Not really sure why such a developed country has airports which are a trial to be in.

commentHeader: tired decor and ripped and torn seats
reviewContent: The C United terminal screams “America’s best days have long departed”. Limited food options, dirty tables, stale packaged food from the kiosks. Overflowing trash bins, tired decor and ripped and torn seats. If I was a lived in Chicago I’d be ashamed to have guests arriving at this terminal. My wife an I travel to many developing nations and most have airports that are newer, cleaner and better.

commentHeader: I will not go through another experience like this in the future
reviewContent: My flight from Europe was late arriving and I was provided a special boarding pass to fast track through the airport and get me to my final destination in Appleton. The first stop was customs. They didn’t care that I was in a hurry to get through to catch my flight. The workers were yelling at people and gave me a look of contempt when I showed them my boarding pass with a red outline which was to guarantee quick access as well as holding my flight through the airport. By the time I got to the counter to check my bag the clerk smiled and said you are 6 minutes too late to catch my flight which wasn’t leaving for 35 minutes. She said I can reschedule you for a flight leaving tomorrow at 3.30 and provide you a discount for a hotel. I lost it after being up for over 24 hours and encountering so many rude workers at that airport. A manger heard me even though I didn’t raise my voice and offered to help. He was able to reschedule me on a flight to Green Bay which was to leave at 7.30. That flight was delayed until 10.30, no reason provided. We didn’t arrive in Green Bay until 11.30, and didn’t arrive home until 12.30. This horrible experience has ended any future travels. As much as I love to travel I will not go through another experience like this in the future. The sad part about my experience is this is the norm not the exception at this airport.

What an embarrassment for the USA. Filthy airport, rude staff, poorly organized, no help at all with directions, border agents very rude, took two hours to clear customs and immigration, staff barking at people, long queues and To repeat, so very rude and unhelpful staff.

An awful awful airport to transit through. Immigration treats you like animals, ventilation is close to nothing, the airport seems to never be on track with time, packed with people and the cleaning is horrendous, the inside looks like a forcefully decorated prison facility. It would be generous to call this an airport. To top it off: a bottle of water bought from inside the domestic airport can’t be taken to your international flight.

I am so astonished by the horrible conditions at this airport. Omicron in the US and people running around maskless. The charging stations seems to be from 2005. There is zero social distancing. Every bar in the place was so jammed with people you would think it was 2018. I have flown through this airport before and thought it was pretty old and poorly run. Now, in the middle of a pandemic and the poor management is shining like a hazard light.

commentHeader: this is incompetence, terrible management and a black eye for our city
reviewContent: You would figure that of all the problems we face in Chicago that at least we could get the ATM tram up and running again. But alas no luck there. Mayor Lightfoot blames this on the pandemic and Canadian boarder closing (contractor) but I remind her that the completion date was originally 2019 before the pandemic. More recent testing showed that the trams had problems in winter weather. Did we forget to mention that we have that in Chicago? As a 100,000 mile a year traveler based here, I'm saying that this is incompetence, terrible management and a black eye for our city, its inexcusable.

commentHeader: Almost no one wore a mask
reviewContent: Almost no one wore a mask. Airport police walked right past people without masks and said nothing. This place is a covid petri dish. Long lines in which no one social distanced.

commentHeader: Train Shuttle has not been working for years
reviewContent: The Train Shuttle has not been working for years and so you’re forced to catch buses between Terminal 5 and the other 3. Buses that frequently get caught up in traffic jams. Now for some bizarre reason they’ve put the Covid Test Site far away on the Bus Terminal meaning a huge long ride if you discover you need to take a test. This wouldn’t be so bad if the train system was working. Unfortunately I live in Chicago and am obliged to use this awful place.

I hope I never have to use this airport again. The staff was rude as I went through security. They assumed I knew their procedure and barked at me with what to do. Finding an outlet to charge my phone wasn’t easy. Was at a table and an entire side had dead outlets and USB ports. The tables for eating and charging stations were also dirty. Did not look like they had been wiped down all day. Is covid not on the rise again?

commentHeader: Incredibly nasty employees at this airport
reviewContent: Incredibly nasty employees at this airport. They are treating the travelers with disrespect. Yelling at me and a group of my friends was their way to get documentation for travel on a domestic flight from Europe. The same at baggage check. I have been to a lot of airports but this one was the worst of the worst. Being treated like a criminal or prisoner is not something I’m used to or enjoy. The wifi was not working and the waiting area was covered with trash. And internet was not working. Shame on you that you employ such nasty people! There was not one employee who would be kind and greeting with a smile. Shame on you that you don’t keep the airport clean. I will always avoid this airport in the future.

This is an absolute garbage airport! There's directions to a drive thru covid testing center for travellers that doesn't exist! I spent a half hour looking for this imaginary testing site. Of that wasn't bad enough when i dropped off my rental car there were no signs to the covid testing center anywhere in the airport! So i kept wandering around asking where i need to go getting conflicted directions! For those of you who don't know its in terminal 2 across the street from the Hilton in the bus shuttle center. I hope that saves you a headache and a back ache. There was at least one nice employee that helped me but most of the staff are always rude! If you can avoid this airport!  They tried telling me i needed a PCR test when the country guidelines clearly said antigen is acceptable for my destination. If i listened i would have had to pay an additional $375 on top of the outrageous price of $120. In Germany they sell a similar antigen test for 3 euros or around $5. If you can avoid ohare do it!!

I have flown several times through O’Hare. Overall, the service has improved significantly but be ready to walk and leave enough time for transit. The food options improved significantly as well. One problem however for international is the transit between terminal 5 (where most but not all international flights leave) and the other terminals - the train between these terminals has been under construction for several years with no end date set (which is absolutely bad management) so avoid international travel if you until the work is done.
The worst ever. 3 hours in line to leave. I will never fly here again. Mexico was put together better. No organization, no information. The worst airport I have ever been to.

commentHeader: Felt like a Covid breeding factory
reviewContent: Worst experience ever coming through customs from Munich. A 2.5-hour line, winding around and around and around before finally getting to the customs line. Everyone in line was disgusted. Felt like a Covid breeding factory. Even though face masks were on, the lines were so long and the area was hot, people had to breathe and dropped masks below their noses. Totally the worst experience I've ever had going through customs at any airport anywhere.

commentHeader: I feel this airport is in need of an entire retraining program!
reviewContent: We flew in late on a flight from Seattle and had to fly from gate G all the way through the tunnels to gate L to find our gate to Syracuse. We were famished after being on the tarmac in Seattle for what seemed like hours! We came upon the one and only food burger "restaurant" on this side of the tunnel and we were completely taken aback when they announced that the restaurant was closed! What? Who is in charge of coordinating this airport? I understand it's late in the day and we are just coming out of covid, but this is ridiculous and, on reading the other comments, I feel this airport is in need of an entire retraining program!

My daughter, special needs unattended minor was left abandoned at this airport by prospect escort and this airport tried to send her off to an outside hotel when she is developmentally delayed IQ below 70 and cannot read or write. I had her on escort services and they abandoned her, thankfully her phone was not dead and I could advocate her and demand they watch her like they were supposed to do. This airport is horrible. I hate what they have done to my daughter and they will do nothing about it except say I should not let her travel in their care.

commentHeader: no food being served in this area
reviewContent: I’m sitting in the concourse that covers gate L 20 to L 24. There are food service counters in this area but there is no food being served in this area. Air travel has been picked up for two weeks now but it can’t open it’s food services when people start traveling. I will be looking at options up to and including changing airlines to avoid this airport in the future. With the people tell you when you ask them at the counter is that it’s due to the pandemic.

commentHeader: ORD provides the worst airport experience I have ever had
reviewContent: If I could rate this airport 1 star, I would. Does Gordon Ramsay fix nightmare airports too? Our flight was delayed with no notification. Gates changed twice, without notification on the loud speaker. Thank goodness I read the email. Our plane was small, hot, and in poor condition. Staff at the help desk were reluctant to assist me, once they assumed I "had a long story", which I didn't even. It was one sentence. The airport itself has dirty restrooms, one of the smaller Starbucks was in a shocking condition. Power outlets throughout the airport do not work. Very sketchy taxi drivers are stationed outside the lower level. This airport in one of America's largest cities should be the standard, American flagship-model airport that other airports around the globe should wish to emulate. Instead, ORD provides the worst airport experience I have ever had! And I have traveled to many different states and countries. This facility should be absolutely ashamed of itself.

commentHeader: the staff there were super rude and disrespectful
reviewContent: Rudest staff I have ever met. Me and my family were looking for help to print our boarding pass and staff were extremely rude and did not help, the staff member treated us as if we were stupid, we just needed help and his attitude was not necessary. After we went in through security and the staff there were super rude and disrespectful. I am very disappointed, If I don’t have to I will never fly here again.

commentHeader: It was just shameful behavior by staff
reviewContent: It is upsetting to know that O’Hare airport is part of our current cultural problems. I am a lifelong resident of the Chicagoland area, and I always believed that we had a pretty good airport. I recently returned home from an international, work-related trip and came across two different employees in Terminal 5 that were extraordinarily rude and disrespectful to not only me, but fellow travelers alongside myself. Instead of helping us along the extensive additional requirements that Covid has brought upon us, employees were incredibly rude. In fact, the final pass through was with a lady that screamed at everyone to stay in line and get their papers ready. I was shocked, and actually already had the paper she was screaming about in my hand. She acted as if we weren’t allowed to travel and shouldn’t be there. Well...here’s reality, I am a single mom with two kids in college, so when my company asks me to travel I do it. I am respectful, had my mask on and bags already in hand and also had the paper she was yelling at us about ready to show her. It was just shameful behavior by staff in terminal 5 at ORD. I am sorry if you hate your job so much that you take it out on people just trying to make it in these difficult times. This is the reason why people are leaving Chicago...let’s all just try and be peaceful and nice.

Chicago O'Hare is generally a reasonable airport though crowded (at least in non-COVID times). I was arriving on United and departing on Turkish, so I arrived at one extreme end of the airport and then had to exit security and take a bus for a long time to get to Terminal 5, then go through security again. Terminal 5 is a weak point of the airport, though it looks like there is a train going in (still outside security). In January 2021 half the lounges are closed and my airline hasn't bothered to make an arrangement with the ones that are open, though that is not exactly the airport's fault. In my past experience, the lounges here are lame compared with those in the United areas, which I could not use since there is no way to get through without leaving security. ORD should organize the Star Alliance carriers to depart from the terminals United uses since international connections are common, it would save all kinds of difficulty for travelers. Terminal 5 may as well be a different airport since you have to allow at least half an hour to get there and leave security, you could make it to Midway airport in not much more time.
Flights were delayed, unavoidable. I was actually appalled at the restaurants on concourse C. Waitstaff were slow, rude and everything was closed at 6.30 pm. 6.30 pm?! It’s Chicago!

O’Hare airport (United) is the worst airport I have ever been to! And I have traveled extensively all over the world. The service is absolutely deplorable. Lazy, arrogant and downright cruel sums up the creatures who work at this place. They lost my luggage and finally after an hour found it back at our gate. They would not bring it to baggage but instead reissued me a boarding pass so I could go back to the gate and get it myself. I was traveling alone with two young children. They had zero compassion and were zero help! Avoid United and this airport from hell!

Requested wheelchair service to American Airlines gate. Upon arrival told to sit in handicap area and someone would help me. Waited and not one person arrived, next employee said check in at kiosk. Did that, told to sit in handicap area again. Very rude and unfriendly employees. A young man arrived with a wheelchair to get another passenger and asked if I needed help. He told me go to baggage to get a special "pass" and someone would come with a wheelchair. My flight was at 1.05pm, Dec 2, 2020. I was at the airport at 10.40 am. I had to get up two more times to ask if someone was coming as it was 12.15 pm and my plane was boarding. One employee snatched it out of my hand to call and see when someone would get me to take me to gate. The purpose of a wheelchair service is so I did not have to walk around everywhere yet I had to anyway to get help. Finally a nice woman arrived, stopped to let me get water and took me all the way on the ramp into the plane. She was kind to me and very apologetic, the only person that was. There was no wi-fi and the place is filthy. I do not think a nonstop flight was worth the nightmare I endured with rude indifferent employees. On that note they could learn from the considerate employees and the cleanliness of the South Carolina airport. Upon returning today, Dec 3, yet another rude employee when I got off the plane she was there with a wheelchair but couldn't sit in it due to other passengers waiting for luggage. Walked the ramp myself then she wheeled me to baggage only after I insisted. She did not speak, just looked at her nails. Very strange young woman, I asked where the restroom was and she said over there somewhere. Big zero rating

commentHeader: The fact that this airport promises any sort of WiFi is an absolute lie
reviewContent: The fact that this airport promises any sort of WiFi is an absolute lie. I tried for hours during my layover to get any sort of a connection to the internet, with no luck. If I was just bored, I would have shrugged my shoulders and moved on, but I had time sensitive work I needed to submit before my flight departed. Thanks to O’Hare and their joke of a WiFi network I wasn’t able to submit assignments for my College classes or do work for my actual job. When you promise your customers WiFi on your website, maybe you should actually make sure, y’know, you can deliver! I absolutely blame O’Hare for this embarrassing problem that hopefully won’t affect my standing at my job or with my professors. Unacceptable! I will go out of my way to never, ever, ever use this airport as a connector on flights ever again.

commentHeader: have plenty of time to spare
reviewContent: Chicago O'Hare Airport is big, very big. You have to take a bus to travel between terminal 1 to terminal 5 which is an International Terminal, may take many hours to pass thru security. It is crazy with a lot of people everywhere. You must prepare ahead, get a good map, direction and know where to go Leave home early and have plenty of time to spare.

commentHeader: the gate was filthy and rundown
reviewContent: My family and I were at gate L5 at Spirit this morning. There was a mouse running around as the gate was filthy and rundown. We reported the mouse and were told by gate agent that it was fine and it would not hurt us. He proceeded to do nothing. I will never fly out of here again.

Flew through United For the first time ever and I just wanted to say that I have never experienced such horrible service. They have so many people standing at the kiosks for no reason at all. Because everything I needed assistance the people was just talking amongst each other and we’re no help at all. I had to go walk and get a lady (the only one that was helping clients) so she could help me too when there were at least 10 other people there. Will never use United from O'hare anymore that’s for sure

Spirit had a 3 hour delay. No problem I could deal with it due to bad weather. We flew out of L9, supposed to be 8.30pm but wound up being 11.50, the area was like an oven, so so hot. Because of the delay we we wanted food and drink. Nothing after 9.30pm unless you wanted McDonalds. How ridiculous for late flights. They cater to early flights and don’t care about people taking later ones. Come on why close the place, it’s crazy.

Seriously every time I fly out of Chicago there is a ridiculous delay. This time another plane was just parked at our gate. Get it together - we’re over a half an hour late which to someone needing to get a connecting flight is beyond annoying.

commentHeader: Complete chaos, inefficiency and lack of knowledge
reviewContent: We had a connecting flight to to RSW. As soon as we got to customs, it was chaos. People were packed into the large room waiting for others to wander around looking for an available kiosk to scan their passport. So unorganized. How about putting the kiosks in a row for people to use while in line? Once finished, we had to stand in long lines again waiting to get checked through. There were only 7 windows open for hundreds of people to funnel through. And, not to sound like "that guy", but they were speeding the non-citizens through a lot faster. 2 were for working visas and students, 5 for citizens and tourists. They should be putting the tourists with the non-citizens. They should also have a line for connecting flights because this is the second time we almost missed our flight due to this mess and we weren't the only ones stressing over a connecting flight. Once we eventually got through, getting our bags was pretty quick and easy, but after that, there were no signs saying where to go next. We just got in the super long line with everyone else. My wife went ahead to talk to someone to make sure we were in the correct place. That person told her that we needed to go outside the huge room to a different place so she ran back and got my son and I and we did as he said. Once we got out and the doors closed behind us, we found out that we were in the right place before and now we had to wait for someone else to come out so we could go back in. We went to to counter to talk to them again and they said to just leave our bags there and go to our flight and they would scan them in for us. I didn't feel comfortable about just leaving our bags next to the counter while they were checking in other people who were waiting in line, but we had no choice. Our flight had started boarding and we were nowhere near the terminal. We missed using the family lane for going through security twice because the lane was roped off. Someone who works there saw us and opened it and they were genuinely surprised that he had to tell us to use it. In all the chaos, we lost one of our boarding passes, so we had to rush to the ticket counter to get a new one printed. She insisted on reprinting all 3 passes even though we only needed 1. After that was done, we started to run to the next step when my wife checked and saw they printed the wrong name on my boarding pass. We decided to just use the old one since it didn't need to be reprinted anyway. It was like she was deliberately wasting our time when we had none to waste. We ran to the tent outside (by the way, we weren't dressed for cold weather because we had no plans to leave the airport so my 7-year-old was freezing right along with us) where we were told to wait for the bus. There were so many people that we had to wait for the next one. We knew we had to go to terminal 1, but when the driver stopped, he never said anything. He just opened the door. Now, I could assume that the first stop is terminal 1, but I hate to make assumptions and get off the bus at the wrong terminal when we're already pressed for time.Luckily, someone else said they could see a "1" outside, so we got off and ran. We made it to our flight while they were almost finished boarding. 2 hours should have been enough time to get through, but it almost wasn't. Complete chaos, inefficiency and lack of knowledge at O'Hare. Can't rate some things because we had no time to use them.

Believe me here when I tell you. I travel for a living as an airline pilot. Forty years + and running. We get moved around on other commercial airlines throughout countries worldwide to and from our trips. The arrival ORD CBP/DHS terminal 5 culture here with our country is so screwed up. They're focusing on the wrong things here. Goods purchases overseas preoccupation and then the fruits, vegetables, fruits, cheeses and the US citizen exemption amounts. When we should be concerned with perpetrators, impostors, criminals and those who wish to our country's entry and to create intentional ill will. Or drugs, etc. The human treatment here is horrible and disrespectful towards it's 'right to be here' US citizens. Especially towards it's born, legal to be here citizens! We're missing the big picture folks.

The customer service at this airport is deplorable and the worst that we've ever experienced at any airport! The customer service interaction/communication at security was unpleasant and down right rude, unprofessional and demeaning! No one smiled or provided eye contact when speaking to you. They were extremely rude and degrading. The desk attendant at Spirit counter was also extremely rude while speaking and giving his speech over the intercom! I pray I never have to fly into this airport again!

My impression is that they are doing everything so you pay extra and enter a business lounge. Crowded and not enough seating facilities, A/C is bad and shops awful. Don't even want to check the bathroom and still have nine hours until my flight. Coming here for a connecting flight had to exit, going through a tent, waiting for a bus.

My wife can’t walk so we needed a wheelchair for her. We have waited over an hour and still no wheelchair. The service here is deplorable. We we told that getting wheelchairs has been privatized and they are pretty slow. We also have a dog that needs to pee and all there is here is concrete. Not very accommodating. This may be our last time flying to O'hare if this isn’t fixed soon.

commentHeader: pretty shocked at how run down it is
reviewContent: The last time I was here was 11 years ago and I am pretty shocked at how run down it is. We're sitting in Terminal C - the seats are broken, the seats are torn in some places and the bathroom are dark and dingy. What's up Chicago? Millions of people travel through your hub every year! Why do you present your city like this? An environment like this also likely causes decreased morale in your staff, they don't seem very happy.

The cowboys that drive those buggies through the terminals beeping and beeping for you to move need shut down. I'm tired of moving off to the side so they can zip through loaded with people too lazy to walk. I'm 72 and I walk. I'm done giving way to those maniacs. Hit me if you want but I'm not going to the wall so you can zip through. Done, no more.

It's almost not even a thought that if I fly out of ORD, I will be delayed, no matter what. It's always technical issues. I can understand weather, but technical and maintenance issues are insane. At least the last 10 flights including the one I get to be stuck on right now is delayed delayed delayed. I never ever fly out of here on time. I hate this airport.

commentHeader: the experience was a real mixed bag
reviewContent: I've never had any particularly negative experience in the times I've flown in and out of O'Hare (although they did lose my luggage in 2014, which was quite annoying). In 2019, the experience was a real mixed bag, first things first, most people I met working at the airport could not have been friendlier or more helpful. A true positive. Even the TSA personnel and incredibly overworked gate agents were patient yet efficient, though, I know this isn't always the case, as with the overworked yet strangely entitled and lackadaisical barista at Starbucks. Oh well, there always seems to have be at least "that one" in airports. However, while I've never had particularly negative experiences, this airport is still not easy to like or embrace. It's clearly outdated, outmoded, and overused, if you've ever watched "Home Alone," which came out in 1990, I'm pretty sure the airport looks today just as it did in 1990 (and even earlier). The airport is dirty all the way around and not well taken care of, even smelling what I can describe as dank and damp in certain areas. Gate seating is not ample. While there are plenty of dining and shopping options both pre- and post-security, many of those options have a sort of dingy feel, no matter how well run they are and how friendly the staff are. The lighting and flooring suck, and even the sporadic display of attractive, futuristic-by-1980s-standards artwork doesn't change that fact. Even though the area of Chicago in which O'Hare is located is generally nice and middle-class, the CTA (Chicago Transit Authority) train station below the terminal has a strangely uncomfortable feeling - and the station and CTA trains are just filthy, even though the station is less than 30 years old (that's CTA's fault, though). Back upstairs, ride shares take longer to arrive and drop off than at many other large airports, even when things aren't particularly crowded. In all, O'Hare provides a poor introduction to, and representation of, an otherwise friendly, vibrant and unique city called Chicago. What a shame.

commentHeader: this was one of the most unpleasant experiences
reviewContent: It was quite busy when I arrived and went to the TSA line # 8. The woman who scanned my boarding pass was just lovely and I couldn’t be happier with her. She took time out of her day to ask how I was and truly meant it. When I went to get my things from the conveyer belt, the woman who was handling the baskets with the basket cart was coming through and I must’ve been in her way and couldn’t move quick enough. She screamed "excuse me!" (Every single person in that line looked at her with wide eyes because of how obnoxiously loud it was) with a huge attitude. So I moved out of the way and I said "oh, I am sorry ma’am". She walked on by ignoring me and then rolling her eyes and laughing with the other TSA woman doing the pat downs. I’m sorry, but I should’ve never been treated that way and this was one of the most unpleasant experiences I have ever been through in an airport. I will make every effort in the future to avoid this airport.

commentHeader: had to wait an excessively long time for my bag
reviewContent: Before I even left my original destination the pilot was told not to take off yet because ORD had too many planes in the air. So we were late taking off. Then we land, have to taxi for 20 minutes to our gate, and then are told our gate is occupied and we have to wait. I had to wait an excessively long time for my bag (had to check it at the gate before leaving my original destination). And then I had to sprint to my connection only to be told boarding closed literally seconds before I got there. The worker surprisingly wasn’t too rude about it, but I was still angry that they couldn’t hold the flight for 2 minutes for myself and 3 other passengers from my original flight. It’s not like the plane left on time anyway. They rebooked me on the next flight out (an hour later) and luckily it wasn’t delayed, but it still took forever to actually take off!

Unbelievably badly organised. The staff try to mask this by constantly shouting at customers and by treating them as if they have perpetrated serious misdemeanours and are under arrest. Guys, we know about security. We really would like your owners to give you better organisation but this isn't our fault so kindly stop yapping and tàke up your issues with management. Also, wearing a uniform does not entitle you to be impolite. I actually experienced a customs officer mimicking my accent. And in the obvious culture of workplace bullying that flourishes in this airport, I was acutely aware that this man clearly wanted me to react so he could pullme out of line. BTW I am an obvious little old lady. The city authorities of Chicago need to be aware that this airport represents them to their incoming visitors, and it does it badly. Really very badly.

Worst airport ever! Do not use for international flights. Absolutely the rudest TSA personnel ever. Very rude when they were screening my carry on. We had very little time for connecting flight and my daughter was using wheelchair assistance - helper was excellent - he was the bright spot. However they held us up as they wiped down wheelchair - which had come from inside a security checkpoints. They also completely patted me down, including crotch area and all over my person. Unbelievably rude bag screening personnel. This was the second horrible experience here coming from London. They also sent our luggage to the East coast. I would avoid this place like the plague.

Horrible! You must leave the secure area, go outside and take a bus to transfer from the international terminal to a connecting flight. The bus is rundown, and there are no markings or PA announcements regarding the various terminal stops. Terminal 2, Concourse E is old, narrow, has inadequate seating at the gates. I’ve seen much better in third world countries!

Awful! Just awful. Hard to find Frontier in the first place, sign is on the back side of the board and not visible from the road, once inside I felt like I was in a cattle car. Gates M1 and M 2 were posted nowhere, hundreds of people milling around, no rep from my airlines anywhere! ne poor airport employee with no mic trying to board people and de-plane multiple persons from multiple flights at the same time. SRO, no room to sit or walk. No flight status updates available in terminal at all and the on line and app info was always at least 1 hour behind actual info. Never again will I fly Frontier or any other airlines through this terminal. I can only hope that Frontier’s attention to operational and customer service details in the air will be 100% better than it is on the ground today!

Terminal 5 is shocking. Nothing works, the train is broken, the toilets are clogged, the security lines are long (and terminal 5 does not even accept precheck!?). The shops are scarcely stocked (except for sundries and candy). Free WiFi requires payment when you click on. Food outlets are overwhelmed. Lounges are among the worst of any major global city. This is Chicago? A world class city? If I had to move my company to Chicago and use terminal 5 I would have to pay extra hardship allowances for my management. Third world conditions affecting the staff who care less about service because they are treated like animals instead of ladies and gentlemen. The board at chicago O’Hare should resign because of the long lasting horror show at terminal 5. And the airlines that pay to use this service should be questioned as well.

My trip home from Brussels was scheduled to connect in Chicago O'Hare, arriving at 1 pm and departing to Houston at 4 pm. My experience in the O'Hare airport was a total nightmare. There were multiple flight delays, and they changed the departure gate three times, with the last change forcing all passengers to go from the C terminal to the B terminal. In the end, the flight to Houston departed at about 10 pm, a delay of 6 hours, and for me a total of 9 hours spent in O'Hare, not knowing when, or if, there would be a flight to Houston that day. There was almost no place to sit, so most of the passengers were forced to stand for hours. This airport is poorly designed, managed horribly, and it does not have enough gates. Anyone returning from overseas should NEVER use O'Hare for a connecting flight.

Never ever use Chicago for international arrivals.
